May liue may loue for what is lyfe but loue?
And loue shall last as long as lyfe remaines,
And lyfe shall end, before my loue depart.

SP.SPEAKER: Mos.
SP.L: Why whats loue, without true constancy?
Lyke to a piller built of many stones.
Yet neither with good morter, well compact,
Nor semell, to fasten it in the ioynts.
But that it shakes with euery blast of winde,
And being toucht, straight falles vnto the earth,
And buries all his haughty pride in dust.
No let our loue be roces of Addamant,
Which time nor place, nor tempest can a sunder.

SP.SPEAKER: Gre.
SP.L: Mosbie leaue protestations now,
And let vs bethinke vs what we haue to doo:
Black Will and shakebag I have placed,
In the broome close watching Ardens comming,
Lets to them, and see what they haue done. Exeunt

SP.SPEAKER: Ard.
SP.P: Of ferry man, where art thou?

SP.SPEAKER: Fer.
SP.L: Here here, goe before to the boat.
And I will follow you.

SP.SPEAKER: Ard.
SP.P: We haue great haste, I pray thée come away.

SP.SPEAKER: Fer.
SP.P: Fy what a mist is here.

SP.SPEAKER: Ard.
SP.L: This mist my frend, is misticall,
Lyke to a good companions smoaky braine,
That was halfe dround with new ale ouer night.

SP.SPEAKER: Fer.
SP.L: I were pitty but his stull were opened,
To make more Chimny roome.

SP.SPEAKER: Fran.
SP.P: Fréend whats thy opinion of this mist.

SP.SPEAKER: Fer.
SP.L: I think tis lyke to a curst wise in a lytlehouse,
That neuer leaues her husband till she haue driuen him out at doores, with a wet paire of eyes,
Then lookes he as if his house were a fire,
Or some of his fréends dead.

SP.SPEAKER: Ard.
SP.P: Speaks thou this of thine owne experience,

SP.SPEAKER: Fer.
SP.P: Perhaps I, perhaps no: For my wyfe is as other women are, that is to say, governed by the Moone.

SP.SPEAKER: Fran.
SP.P: By the Moone, how I pray thée?

SP.SPEAKER: Fer.
SP.L: Na thereby lyes a bargane.
And you shall not haue it fresh and fasting.

SP.SPEAKER: Ard.
SP.P: Yes I pray thee good ferryman.

SP.SPEAKER: Fer.
SP.L: Then for this once, let it be midsommer Moone,
But yet my wyfe as another moone.

SP.SPEAKER: Fran.
SP.P: Another Moone.

SP.SPEAKER: Fer.
SP.P: I, and it hath influences and Celipses.

SP.SPEAKER: Ard.
SP.L: Why then by this reconing, you somtimes
Play the man in the Moone.

SP.SPEAKER: Fer.
SP.L: I but you had not best to meddle with that moone
Least I scratch you by the face, with my bramble bush,

SP.SPEAKER: Ard.
SP.P: I am almost stifled with this fog, come lets away

SP.SPEAKER: Fran.
SP.P: And sirra as we go, lets vs haue som more of your bolde yeomandry.

SP.SPEAKER: Fer.
SP.P: Nay by my troth sir, but flat knauery. Exeunt.

DIV1.STAGE: Here enters Will at one doore, and Shakbag at another.

SP.SPEAKER: Sha.
SP.P: Oh Will where art thou?

SP.SPEAKER: Wil.
SP.L: Here shakbag, almost in hels mouth,
Where I can not see my way for smoake.

SP.SPEAKER: Sha.
SP.P: I pray thee speake still, that we may mete by the sound, for I shall fall into some ditche or other, vnles my seete see better then my eies.

SP.SPEAKER: Wil.
SP.P: Didest thou euer sée better weather to runne a∣way with another mans wife, or play with a wenche at potfinger.

SP.SPEAKER: shak.
SP.L: No this were a sine world for chandlers,
If this weather would last, for then a man
Should neuer dyne nor sup without candle light,
But sirra Will what horses are those that past?

SP.SPEAKER: Wil.
SP.P: Why, didst thou heare any?

SP.SPEAKER: Sha.
SP.P: I that I did.

SP.SPEAKER: Will.
SP.L: My life for thine, twas Arden and his companiō
And then all our labour's lost,

SP.SPEAKER: Sha.
SP.L: Nay say not so for, if it be they, they may happely loose their way as we haue done
And then we may chaunce meete with them.

SP.SPEAKER: Wil.
SP.P: Come let vs go on lyke a couple of blind pilgrims

DIV1.STAGE: Then Shakebag falles into a ditch.

SP.SPEAKER: Sha.
SP.P: Helpe Will help, I am almost drownd.

SP.SPEAKER: Fer.
SP.P: Whose that, that calles for help?

SP.SPEAKER: Wil.
SP.P: I was none heere, twas thou thy selfe.

SP.SPEAKER: Fer.
SP.L: I came to help him that cald for help,
Why how now? who is this thats in the ditch?
You are well enough serued, to goe without a guyde such weather as this.

SP.SPEAKER: Wil.
SP.P: Sirra what companyes hath past your ferry this morning

SP.SPEAKER: Fer.
SP.P: None but a cupple of gentlemen, that went to dyne at my Lord cheyneis.

SP.SPEAKER: Wil.
SP.P: Shakbag did not I tell thée asmuch?

SP.SPEAKER: Fer.
SP.P: Why sir, will you haue any letters caried to them

SP.SPEAKER: Wil.
SP.P: No sir, get you gone.

SP.SPEAKER: Fer.
SP.P: Did you euer see such a mist as this?

SP.SPEAKER: Wil.
SP.P: No, nor such a foole as will rather be bought then get his way.

SP.SPEAKER: Fer.
SP.L: Why sir, this is no hough munday, you ar deceiud
Whats his name I pray you sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Sha.
SP.P: His name is black will.

SP.SPEAKER: Fer.
SP.P: I hope to see him one day hangd vpon a hill.

SP.SPEAKER: Sha.
SP.L: Sée how the Sunne hath cleard the foggy mist,
Now we haue mist the marke of our intent.

STAGE.HI: Here enters Grene Mosbye and Ales.

SP.SPEAKER: Mos.
SP.L: Black Will and Shakbag, what make you héer
VVhat is the deed don? is Arden dead.

SP.SPEAKER: Wil.
SP.L: VVhat could a blynded man performe in armes?
Saw you not how till now, the sky was darke,
That neither horse nor man could be decerned,
Yet did we heare their horses as they past.

SP.SPEAKER: Gre.
SP.P: Haue they escapt you then, and past the ferry?

SP.SPEAKER: Sha.
SP.L: I for a while, but here we two will stay.
And at their comming back meete with them once more,
Zounds I was nere so toylde in all my lyfe,
In following so slight a taske as this.

SP.SPEAKER: Mos.
SP.P: Now camst thou so beraide?

SP.SPEAKER: Wil.
SP.L: VVith making false footing in the dark,
He needs would follow them without a guide.

SP.SPEAKER: Ales.
SP.L: Here's to pay for a fire and good chéere
Get you to Feuershame to the flowre deluce,
Andrest your selues vntil some other time.

SP.SPEAKER: Gre.
SP.P: Let me alone, it most concernes my state.

SP.SPEAKER: Wil.
SP.L: I mistres Arden this wil serue the turne,
In case we fal into a second fog.

SP.SPEAKER: Mos.
SP.P: These knaues wil neuer do it, let vs giue it ouer

SP.SPEAKER: Ales.
SP.L: First tell me how you like my new deuice?
Soone when my husband is returning back,
You and I both marching arme in arme,
Lyke louing frends wele meete him on the way.
And boldly beard and braue him to his teeth:
VVhen words grow hot, and blowes beginne to ryse,
Ile call those cutters foorth your tenement,
VVho in a manner to take vp the fray,
Shall wound my husband hornesbie to the death.

SP.SPEAKER: Mos.
SP.P: Ah fine deuise, why this deserues a kisse. Exeunt.

DIV1.STAGE: Here enters Dicke Reede and a Sailer.

SP.SPEAKER: Sayler.
SP.L: Faith Dick Rede it is to lytle end.
His conscience is too liberall, and he too nigardly.
To parte from any thing may doo thée good.

SP.SPEAKER: Rede
SP.L: He is comming from Shorlow as I vnderstand,
Here ile intercept him, for at his house
He neuer will vouchafe to speake with me:
If prayers and faire intreaties will not serue,
Or make no battry in his flintye breast. Here enters Fra. Ard. and Michaell.
Ile cursse the carle and sée what that will do.
Se where he comes, to further my intent,
M. Arden I am now bound to the sea,
My comming to you was about the plat of ground,
Which wrongfully you detaine from me.
Although the rent of it be very small,
Yet will it helpe my wife and children:
Which here I leaue in Feuershame God knowes,
Needy and bare, for Christ sake let them haue it,

SP.SPEAKER: Ard.
SP.L: Francklin hearest thou this fellow speake?
That which he craues I dearely bought of him,
Although the rent of it was euer mine.
Sirra you, that aske these questions,
If with thy clamarous impeaching tongue
Thou raile on me, as I haue heard thou dost,
He lay thée vp so close a twelue months day,
As thou shalt neither sée the Sonne nor Moone,
Looke to it, for as surely as I liue,
Ile banish pittie if thou vse me thus.

SP.SPEAKER: Rede.
SP.L: What wist thou do me wrong, & threat me too?
Nay then Ile tempt thee, Arden doo thy worst,
God I beseech thee show some miracle,
On thée or thine, in plauging thée for this.
That plot of ground, which thou detaines from me,
I speake it in an agony of spirite,
Be ruinous and fatall vnto thée:
Either there be butcherd by thy dearest fréends,
Or els be brought for men to wonder at.
Or thou or thine miscary in that place.
Or there runne mad, and end thy cursed dayes,

SP.SPEAKER: Fra.
SP.L: Fy bitter knaue brydle thine enuious tongue,
For curses are like arrowes shot vpright,
Which falling doun light on the sutors head.

SP.SPEAKER: Rede.
SP.L: Light where they will, were I vppon the sea,
As oft I haue in many a bitter storme,
And said a dreadfull suthern flaw at hand,
The Pylate quaking at the doubtfull storme,
And all the saylers praying on their knees,
Euen in that fearefull time would I fall down,
And aske of God, what ere betide of me,
Vengeance on Arden, or some misevent,
To shewe the world, what wrong the carle hath done,
This charge Ile leaue with wy distresfull wife.
My children shall be taught such praiers as these,
And thus I go but leaue my curse with thee.

SP.SPEAKER: Ard.
SP.L: It is the raylingest knaue in christendome,
And oftentimes the villaine will be mad,
It greatly matters not what he sayes,
But I assure you, I nere did him wrong.

SP.SPEAKER: Fra.
SP.P: I think so M. Arden.

SP.SPEAKER: Ard.
SP.L: Now that our horses are gone home before,
My wife may hapely mete me on the way,
For God knowes she is growne passing kinde of late,
And greatly chaunged from the oulde humor
Of her wounted frowardnes.
And seekes by faire meanes to redeeme ould faults.

SP.SPEAKER: Fra.
SP.L: Happy the change, that alters for the best,
But see in any case you make no speache,
Of the cheare we had at my Lord Cheineis,
Although most bounteous and liberall,
For that will make her think her selfe more wrongd,
In that we did carry her a long,
For sure she greeued that she was left behinde,
Come Francklin, let vs strain to mend our pace,
And take her vnawares playing the cooke. Here enters Ales and Mosbie.
For I beléeue sheele stryue to mend our chéere.

SP.SPEAKER: Fran.
SP.L: Why thers no better creaturs in the world
Then women are, when they are in good humors.

SP.SPEAKER: Ard.
SP.L: Who is that? Mosbie, what so familiare?
Iniurious strumpet, and thou ribald knaue,
Unt wyne those armes.

SP.SPEAKER: Ales.
SP.P: I with a sugred kisse, let them vntwine.

SP.SPEAKER: Ard.
SP.P: Ah Mosbie, perturde beast, beare this and all.

SP.SPEAKER: Mos.
SP.L: And yet no horned beast,
The hornes are thine.

SP.SPEAKER: Fran.
SP.P: O monstrous, Nay then tis time to draw.

SP.SPEAKER: Ales
SP.P: Helpe helpe, they murther my husband.

SP.SPEAKER: Sha.
SP.L: Zounds who iniures M. Mosbie.
Help Wil I am hurt.

SP.SPEAKER: Mos.
SP.P: I may thank you Mistres arden for this wound,

SP.SPEAKER: Ales.
SP.L: Ah Arden what folly blinded thee?
Ah Ielious harebraine man what hast thou don,
When we to welcome thy intended sport.
Came louingly to mete thee on thy way.
Thou drewst thy sword inraged with Ielousy,
And hure thy freende,
Whose thoughts were frée from harme.
All for a woorthles kisse, and ioyning armes.
Both don but mirely to try thy patience.
And me vnhappy that deuysed the Iest,
Which though begonne in sporte, yet ends in bloode.

SP.SPEAKER: Fran.
SP.P: Mary God defend me from such a Ieast.

SP.SPEAKER: Ales.
SP.L: Could thou not see vs frendly smyle on thée.
When we ioynd armes and when I kist his cheeke.
Hast thou not lately found me ouer kinde?
Didst thou not heare me cry they murther thee.
Cald I not helpe to set my husband frée:
No, eares and all were witcht, ah me accurst,
To lincke in lyking with a frantick man,
Hence foorth Ile be thy slaue, no more thy wife:
For with that name I neuer shall content thee.
If He merry thou straight waies thinks me light.
If sad thou satest the sullens trouble me.
If well attyred thou thinks I will be gadding,
If homely, I seeme sluttish in thine eye.
Thus am I still, and shall be whill I die,
Poore wench abused by thy misgovernment,

SP.SPEAKER: Ard.
SP.L: But is it for trueth, that neither thou nor he,
Entendedst malice in your misdemeanor.

SP.SPEAKER: Ales.
SP.P: The heauens can witnes of our harmles thoghts

SP.SPEAKER: Ard.
SP.L: Then pardon me sweete Ales,
And forgiue this faulte:
Forget but this, and neuer sée the lyke.
Impose me pennance, and I will performe it:
For in thy discontent I finde a death,
A death tormenting more then death it selfe,

SP.SPEAKER: Ales.
SP.L: Nay hadst thou loued me as thou doest pretend,
Thou wouldst haue markt the speaches of thy frend,
Who going wounded from the palce, he said
His skinne was peirst only through my deuise,
And if sad so row taint thee for this falt,
Thou wouldst haue followed him, and sene him drest,
And cryde him mercy whome thou hast misdone,
Nere shall my hart be cased till this be done.

SP.SPEAKER: Arden.
SP.L: Content thee sweet Ales thou shalt haue thy wil
What ere it be, For that I iniurde thee
And wrongd my frend, shame scourgeth my offence,
Come thou thy selfe and go along with me,
And be a mediator twixt vs two.

SP.SPEAKER: Fran.
SP.L: Why M. Arden, know you what you do,
Will you follow him that hath dishonourd you,

SP.SPEAKER: Ales.
SP.P: Why canst thou proue I haue bene disloyall.
Why Mosbie traunt you husband with the horn,

SP.SPEAKER: Ales.
SP.L: I after he had reuyled him,
By the iniuryous name of periurde beast,
He knew no wrong could spyte an Ielious man,
More then the hatefull naming of the horne.

SP.SPEAKER: Fran.
SP.L: Suppose tis trew, yet is it dangerous.
To follow him whome he hath lately hurt,

SP.SPEAKER: Ales.
SP.L: A fault confessed is more then halfe a mends,
But men of such ill spirite as your selfe.
Worke crosses and debates twixt man and wife.

SP.SPEAKER: Ard.
SP.L: I pray the gentle Francklin holde thy peace,
I know my wife consels me for the best,

SP.SPEAKER: Ard.
SP.L: Ile seeke out mosby, where his wouud is drest,
And salue his haples quarell if I may.

SP.SPEAKER: Fran.
SP.L: He whome the diuel driues must go perforce,
Poore gentleman how sone he is bewitcht,
And yet because his wife is the instrument,
His frends must not be laush in their speach, Exit Fran.

SP.SPEAKER: Wil.
SP.P: Sirra Greene when was I so long in killing a man.

SP.SPEAKER: Gre.
SP.L: I think we shall neuer do it.
Let us giue it ouer.

SP.SPEAKER: Sha.
SP.L: Nay Zounds wele kill him.
Though we be hangd at his dore for our labour.

SP.SPEAKER: Wil.
SP.L: Thou knowest Greene that I have lived in
London this twelve yeers.
Where I have made some go uppon wodden legges,
For taking the wall on me,
Dyuers with siluer noses, for saying,
There goes blackwill.
I have crackt as many blades,
As thou hast done Nutes,

SP.SPEAKER: Gre.
SP.P: O monstrous lye.

SP.SPEAKER: Will.
SP.L: Faith in a manner I haue.
The bawdie houses haue paid me tribute,
There durst not a whore set vp, vnlesse she haue aggreed
with me first, for-opning her shoppe windowes.
For a crosee worde of a Tapster,
I haue pearced one barrell after another, with my dager,
And held him be the eares till all his beare hath run out,
In Temes streete a brewers carte was lyke to haue runne
ouer me, I made no more ado, but went to the clark
and cut all the natches of his tales,
and beat them about his head.
I and my companye haue taken the Constable from his watch,
And carried him about the fields on a coltstaffe.
I haue broken a Sariants head with his owne mace,
And build whome I list with my sword and buckler.
All the tenpenny alehouse would stand euery morning,
With a quart pot in his had,
Saying will it please your worship drinke:
He that had not doone so had beene sure to haue had tis
Singne puld down, & his latice borne away the next right
To conclude, what haue I not done it cannot do this,
Doubtles he is preserued by Miracle.

SP.SPEAKER: Gie.
SP.P: Hence Will, here comes M. Arden.

SP.SPEAKER: Ales.
SP.P: Ah gentle michaell art thou sure their frends

SP.SPEAKER: Mic.
SP.L: Why I saw them when they both shoke hands,
When Mosbie bled, he euen wept for sorrow:
And raild on Francklin that was cause of all.
No sooner came the Surgen in at doores,
But my M. tooke to his purse, and gaue him money.
And to conclude, sent me to bring you word,
That Mosbie, Francklin, Bradshaw, Adam fewle,
With diuers of his neighbors, and his frends,
Will come and sup with you at our house this night.

SP.SPEAKER: Ales.
SP.L: Ah gentle Michaell, runne thou bak againe,
And when my husband walkes into the faire,
Bid Mosbie steale from him, and come to me.
And this night shal thou and Susan be made sure,

SP.SPEAKER: Mic.
SP.P: Ile go tell him.

SP.SPEAKER: Ales.
SP.L: And as thou goest, tell Iohn cooke of our guests,
And bid him lay it on, spare for no coast. Exit Michaell.

SP.SPEAKER: Wil.
SP.L: Nay and there be such cheere, we wil bid our selues
Mistres Arden, Dick Greene & I do meane to sup wt you,

SP.SPEAKER: Ales.
SP.L: And welcome shall you be, ah gentlemen,
Now must you of your purpose yesternight?

SP.SPEAKER: Gre.
SP.P: Twas long of shakbag that vnluckye villaine.

SP.SPEAKER: Sha.
SP.P: Thou doest me wrong, I did as much as any.

SP.SPEAKER: Wil.
SP.L: Nay, then M. Ales, Ile tell you how it was,
When he should haue lockt with both his huts,
He to a brauery florisht ouer his head
With that comes Francklin at him lustely
And hurts the slaue, with that he slinks away,
Now his way had bene to haue come hand and féete,
one and two round at his costerd.
He lyke a loose beares his sword point halfe a yarde out
of danger, I lye here for m lyfe.
If the deuil come, and he haue no more strength then sence
He shall neuer beat me from this warde,
He stand to it, a buckler in a skilfull hand,
Is as good as a castell.
Nay tis better then a sconce, for I haue tryde it.
Mosbie perceiuing this, began to faint.
With that comes Arden with his arming sword,
And thrust him through the shoulder in a tryce.

SP.SPEAKER: Ales.
SP.L: I but I wonder why you both stoode still.

SP.SPEAKER: Wil.
SP.P: Faith I was so amazed I could not strike.

SP.SPEAKER: Ales.
SP.L: Ah sirs had he yesternight bene slaine,
For euery drop of his detested bloode,
I would cranime in Angels in thy fist.
And kist thee too, and hugd thee in my armes.

SP.SPEAKER: Wil.
SP.L: Patient your selfe, we can not help it now,
Greene and we two, will dogge him through the faire,
And stab him in the croud, and steale away,

SP.SPEAKER: Ales.
SP.L: It is vnpossible, but here comes he,
That will I hope inuent some surer meanes.
Swete Mosbie hide thy arme, it kils my hart.

SP.SPEAKER: Mos.
SP.P: I mistres Arden, this is your fauour,

SP.SPEAKER: Ales.
SP.L: Ah say not so for when I sawe thee hurt,
I could haue toke the weapon thou letst fall,
And cunne at Arden, for I haue sworne,
That these mine eyes offended with his sight,
Shall neuer close, til Ardens be shut vp,
This night I rose and walkt about the chamber.
And twise or thrise, I thought to haue murthred him,

SP.SPEAKER: Mos.
SP.P: What in the night, then had we bene vndone,

SP.SPEAKER: Ales
SP.P: Why, how long shall he liue?

SP.SPEAKER: Mos
SP.L: Fraith Ales no longer then this night.
Black Will and shakbag, will you two
Performe the complot that I haue laid.

SP.SPEAKER: Will.
SP.P: I or els think me as a villaine.

SP.SPEAKER: Gre.
SP.L: And rather then you shall want,
He help my selfe.

SP.SPEAKER: Mos.
SP.L: You M. Greene shal single Francklin foorth,
And hould him with a long tale of strange newes:
That he may not come home till suppertime.
Ile fetch M. Arden home, & we like frends.
Will play a game or two at tables here,

SP.SPEAKER: Ales
SP.L: But what of all this?
Now shall he be staine?

SP.SPEAKER: Mosbie
SP.L: Why black Wil and shakebag lockt within the countinghouse,
Shall at a certaine watchword giuen, rush foorth,

SP.SPEAKER: Wil.
SP.P: What shall the watch word be?

SP.SPEAKER: Mos.
SP.L: (Now I take you) that shall be the word.
But come not forth before in any case.

SP.SPEAKER: Wil.
SP.P: I warrant you, but who shall lock me in?

SP.SPEAKER: Ales.
SP.P: That will I do, thou'st kepe the key thy selfe.

SP.SPEAKER: Mos.
SP.L: Come M. Gréene, go you along with me.
Sée all things ready Ales against we come.

SP.SPEAKER: Ales.
SP.L: Take no care for that, send you him home. Exeunt Mosbie and Greene.
And if he ere go forth againe, blame me,
Come blacke Will that in mine eies art faire,
Next vnto Mosbie doe I honour thée,
Instead of faire wordes and large promises,
My hands shall play you goulden harmonie,
Now like you this? say, will you doe it sirs?

SP.SPEAKER: Will.
SP.L: I and that brauely too, marke my deuice.
Place Mosbie being a stranger in a chaire,
And let your husband sit vpon a stoole,
That I may come behind him cunninglie,
And with a to well pull him to the ground,
Then stab him till his flesh be as a sine,
That doone beare him behind the Abby,
That those that finde him murthered, may suppose
Some slaue or other kild him for his golde.

SP.SPEAKER: Ales.
SP.L: A fine deuice, you shall haue twenty pound,
And when he is dead, you shal haue forty more.
And least you might be suspected staying heere,
Michaell shall saddle you two lusty geldings.
Ryde whether you will to Scotland or to Wales.
He see you shall not lacke, where ere you be.

SP.SPEAKER: Wil
SP.L: Such wordes would make one kill 1000. men.
Giue me the key, which is the counting house?

SP.SPEAKER: Ales.
SP.L: Here would I stay, and still encourage you,
But that I know how resolute you are.

SP.SPEAKER: Sha.
SP.P: Lush you are too faint harted, we must do it.

SP.SPEAKER: Ales.
SP.L: But Mosbie will be there, whose very lookes,
Will ad vnwounted courage to my thought,
And make me the first that shall aduenture on him,

SP.SPEAKER: Wil.
SP.L: Lush get you gone, tis we must do the deede.
When this doore oppens next looke for his death

SP.SPEAKER: Ales.
SP.L: Ah, would be now were here, that it might oppen
I shaling more be closed in Ardens armes,
That lyke the snakes of blacke Tisiphone,
Sting me with their enbraceings, mosbies armes
Shal compasse me, and were I made a starre,
I would haue none other spheres but those.
There is no nedor, but in Mosbies lypes,
Had chast Diana kist him, she like me
Would grow loue sicke, and from her watrie bower,
Fling down Endimion and snath him vp:
Then blame not me, that stay a silly man,
Not halfe so louely as Endimion.

SP.SPEAKER: Mic.
SP.P: Mistres my maister is comming hard by,

SP.SPEAKER: Ales.
SP.P: Who comes with him.

SP.SPEAKER: Mic.
SP.P: No body but mosbye.

SP.SPEAKER: Ales.
SP.L: Thats will michaell, fetch in the tables,
And when thou hast done, stand before the countinghouse doore.

SP.SPEAKER: Mic.
SP.P: Why so?

SP.SPEAKER: Ales.
SP.P: Black will is lockt within, to do the déede.

SP.SPEAKER: Mic,
SP.P: What shull he die to night?

SP.SPEAKER: Ales.
SP.P: I michaell▪

SP.SPEAKER: Mic.
SP.P: But shall not susan know it?

SP.SPEAKER: Ales.
SP.P: Yes for shele be as seereete as our selues.

SP.SPEAKER: Mic.
SP.P: Thats braue, Ile go fetch the tables.

SP.SPEAKER: Ales.
SP.L: But michaell hearke to me a word or two,
When my husband is come in lock the streete doore:
He shall be murthred or the guests come in. Exit mic, Here enters Arden & Mosbie.
Husband what meane you to bring mosby home?
Although I wisht you to be reconciled,
Twas more for feare of you, then loue of him,
Black Will and Greene, are his companions,
And they are cutters, and may cut you shorte,
Therefore I thought it good to make you frends.
But wherefore do you bring him hether now,
You haue giuen me my supper with his sight,

SP.SPEAKER: Mos.
SP.P: M. Arden me thinks your wife would haue me gone.

SP.SPEAKER: Arden.
SP.L: No good M. Mosbie, women will be prating,
Ales bid him welcome, he and I are frends.

SP.SPEAKER: Ales
SP.L: You may inforce me to it, if you will.
But I had rather die then bid him welcome,
Die company hath purchest me ill frends.
And therefore wil I nere frequent it more.

SP.SPEAKER: Mos.
SP.P: Oh how cunningly she can dissemble.

SP.SPEAKER: Ard.
SP.P: Now he is here you wil not serue me so.

SP.SPEAKER: Ales.
SP.L: I pray you be not angree or displeased
Ile bid him welcome seing youle haue it so,
You are welcome M. Mosbie will you sit down.

SP.SPEAKER: Mos.
SP.L: I know I am welcome to your louing husband,
But for your selfe, you speake not from your hart.

SP.SPEAKER: Ales.
SP.P: And if I do not, sir think I haue cause.

SP.SPEAKER: Mos.
SP.P: Pardon me M. Arden, Ile away.

SP.SPEAKER: Ard.
SP.P: No good M. Mosbie.

SP.SPEAKER: Ales.
SP.P: We shal haue guests enough, thogh you go hence

SP.SPEAKER: Mos.
SP.P: I pray you M. Arden let me go

SP.SPEAKER: Ard.
SP.P: I pray thee Mosbie let her prate her fill,

SP.SPEAKER: Ale.
SP.P: The dores are open sir, you may be gone.

SP.SPEAKER: Mic.
SP.P: Nay thats a lye, for I haue lockt the dores.

SP.SPEAKER: Ard.
SP.L: Sirra fetch me a cup of Wine.
Ile make them freends.
And gentle M. Ales, seeing you are so stout,
You shal beginne, frowne not, Ile haue it so.

SP.SPEAKER: Ales
SP.P: I pray you meddle with that you haue to do.

SP.SPEAKER: Ard.
SP.L: Why Ales? how can I do too much for him,
Whose lyfe I haue endaungered without cause.

SP.SPEAKER: Ale.
SP.L: Tis true, & seeing twas partly through my means
I am content to drinke to him for this once.
Here M. Mosbie, and I pray you hence forth,
Be you as straunge to me, as I to you
Your company hath purchased me ill freends.
And I for you God knowes, haue vndeserued
Beene ill spoken of in euery place.
Therefore hencefoorth frequent my house no more.

SP.SPEAKER: Mos.
SP.L: Ile see your husband in dispight of you,
Yet Arden I protest to thee by heauen,
Thou nere shalt see me more, after this night.
Ile go to Roome rather then be forsworne.

SP.SPEAKER: Ar.
SP.P: Tush Ile haue no such vowes made in my house.

SP.SPEAKER: Ales.
SP.L: Yes I pray you husband let him sweare,
And on that condition Mosbie pledge me here.

SP.SPEAKER: Mos.
SP.P: I as willingly as I meane to liue.

SP.SPEAKER: Ard.
SP.P: Come Ales, is our supper ready yet?

SP.SPEAKER: Ales.
SP.P: It wil by then you haue plaid a game at tables,

SP.SPEAKER: Ard.
SP.P: Come M. Mosbie, what shall we play for?

SP.SPEAKER: Mos.
SP.P: Thrée games for a french crowne sir,
And please you.

SP.SPEAKER: Ard.
SP.P: Content.

DIV1.STAGE: Then they play at the Tables.

SP.SPEAKER: Wil
SP.P: Can he not take him yet? what a spight is that?

SP.SPEAKER: Ales
SP.P: Not yet Will, take hede he see thee not?

SP.SPEAKER: Wil.
SP.P: I feare he will spy me, as I am coming,

SP.SPEAKER: Mic.
SP.P: To preuent that, creepe betwixt my legs

SP.SPEAKER: Mos.
SP.P: One ace, or els I lose the game.

SP.SPEAKER: Ard.
SP.P: Mary sir theres two for fayling.

SP.SPEAKER: Mos.
SP.P: Ah M. Arden (now I can take you)

DIV1.STAGE: Then Will pulles him down with a towell

SP.SPEAKER: Ard.
SP.P: Mosbie, Michaell, Ales, what will you do?

SP.SPEAKER: Will
SP.P: Nothing but take you vp sir, nothing els.

SP.SPEAKER: Mos.
SP.P: Thers for the pressing Iron you tould me of.

SP.SPEAKER: Sha.
SP.P: And ther's for the ten pound in my sleeue,

SP.SPEAKER: Ales.
SP.L: What, grones thou? nay then giue me y• weapō,
Take this for hindring Mosbies loue and mine.

SP.SPEAKER: Michaell.
SP.P: D Mistres.

SP.SPEAKER: Will
SP.P: Ah that villaine wil betray vs all,

SP.SPEAKER: Mos.
SP.P: Tush feare him not, he will be secrete,

SP.SPEAKER: Mic.
SP.P: Why dost thou think I will betray my selfe?

SP.L: In South warke dwels a bonnie northerne lasse,
The widow Chambley, ile to her house now,
Ind if she will not giue me harborough,
He make bootie of the queane euen to her smocke.

SP.SPEAKER: Will.
SP.P: Shift for your selues we two will leaue you now

SP.SPEAKER: Ales.
SP.P: First lay the bodie in the countinghouse.

DIV1.STAGE: Then they lay the body in the Countinghouse.

SP.SPEAKER: Will.
SP.L: We haue our gould mistris Ales, adew,
Mosbie farewell, and Michaell farewell too. Exeunt

SP.SPEAKER: Susan.
SP.L: Mistres, the guests are at the doores.
Hearken they knocke, what shall I let them in?

SP.SPEAKER: Ales.
SP.L: Mosbie go thou & beare them companie. Exit. M.
And susan fetch water and wash away this bloode,

SP.SPEAKER: Susan.
SP.P: The bloode cleaueth to the ground & will not out

SP.SPEAKER: Ales.
SP.L: But with my nailes ile scrape away the blood,
The more I striue the more the blood appeares:

SP.SPEAKER: Susan.
SP.P: Whats the reason M. can you tell?

SP.SPEAKER: Ales.
SP.P: Because I blush not at my husbands death.

SP.SPEAKER: Mos.
SP.P: Now now, whats the matter? is all well?

SP.SPEAKER: Ale.
SP.L: I wel, if Arden were aliue againe.
In vaine we striue, for here his blood remains,

SP.SPEAKER: Mos.
SP.L: Why strew rushes on it, can you not,
This wench doth nothing fall vnto the worke.

SP.SPEAKER: Ales.
SP.P: Twas thou that made me murther him,

SP.SPEAKER: Mos.
SP.P: What of that?

SP.SPEAKER: Ales.
SP.P: Nay nothing Mosbie so it be not known.

SP.SPEAKER: Mos.
SP.P: Kéepe thou it close, and tis vnpossible,

SP.SPEAKER: Ales.
SP.L: Ah but I can not, was he not staine by me,
My husbands death torments me at the hart.

SP.SPEAKER: Mos.
SP.L: It shall not long torment thee gentle Ales,
I am thy husband, thinke no more of him.

DIV1.STAGE: Here enters Adam fowle and Brad,

SP.SPEAKER: Brad.
SP.P: Now now M. Arden? what ayle you wéepe?

SP.L: Because her husband is abroad so late.
A cupple of Ruffins threatned him yesternight,
And she poore soule is affraid he should be hurt.

SP.SPEAKER: Adam
SP.P: It nothing els? tush hele be here anone.

SP.SPEAKER: Gre.
SP.P: Now M. Arden lacke you any guests.

SP.SPEAKER: Ales.
SP.P: Ah M. Greene, did you se my husband lately,

SP.SPEAKER: Gre.
SP.P: I saw him walking behinde the Abby euen now,

SP.SPEAKER: Ales.
SP.L: I do not like this being out so late,
M. Francklin where did you leaue my husband.

SP.SPEAKER: Fra.
SP.L: Beleeue me I saw him not since Morning,
Feare you not hele come anone, meane time
You may do well to bid his guests sit down.

SP.SPEAKER: Ales.
SP.L: I so they shall, M. Bradshaw sit you there,
I pray you be content, Ile haue my will.
M. Mosbie sit you in my husbands seat.

SP.SPEAKER: Michaell
SP.L: Susan shall thou and I wait on them,
Or and thou saith the word let vs sit down too.

SP.SPEAKER: Su.
SP.L: Peace we haue other matters now in hand.
I feare me Michael al wilbe bewraied.

SP.SPEAKER: Mic.
SP.L: Tush so it be knowne that I shal marry thée in the
Morning, I care not though I be hangde ere night.
But to preuent the worst, Ile by some rats bane.

SP.SPEAKER: Su.
SP.P: Why Michael wilt thou poyson thy selfe?

SP.SPEAKER: Mic.
SP.P: No, but my mistres, for I feare shele tell.

SP.SPEAKER: Su.
SP.P: Tush Michel feare not her, she's wise enough.

SP.SPEAKER: Mos.
SP.L: Sirra Michell giues a cup of beare.
M. Arden, heers to your husband.

SP.SPEAKER: Ales.
SP.P: My husband?

SP.SPEAKER: Fra.
SP.P: What ailes you woman, to crie so suddenly.

SP.SPEAKER: Ales.
SP.L: Ah neighbors a sudden qualm came ouer my hart
My husbands being foorth torments my minde.
I know some thing's amisse, he is not well.
Or els I should haue heard of him ere now.

SP.SPEAKER: Mo.
SP.P: She will vndo vs, through her foolishnes.
Feare not M. Arden, he's well enough.

SP.SPEAKER: Ales.
SP.L: Tell not me, I know he is not well,
He was not wount for to stay thus late.
Good M. Francklin go and seeke him foorth,
And if you finde him send him home to mee.
And tell him what a feare he hath put me in.

SP.SPEAKER: Fra.
SP.L: Ilyke not this, I pray God all be well Exeunt Fra. Mos. & Gre.
Ile seeke him out, and find him if I can.

SP.SPEAKER: Ales.
SP.P: Michaell how shall I doo to rid the rest away?

SP.SPEAKER: Mic.
SP.L: Leaue that to my charge, let me alone,
Tis very late M. Bradshaw,
And there are many false knaues abroad,
And you haue many narrow lanes to pas.

SP.SPEAKER: Brad.
SP.L: Faith frend Michaell and thou saiest trew,
Therefore I pray thee lights foorth, and lends a linck

SP.SPEAKER: Ales.
SP.L: Michael bring them to the dores, but doo not stay,
You know I do not loue to be alone.
Go Susan and bid thy brother come,
But wherefore should he come? Heere is nought but feare.
Stay Susan stay, and helpe to counsell me.

SP.SPEAKER: Susan.
SP.P: Alas I counsell, feare frights away my wits,

DIV1.STAGE: Then they open the countinghouse doore, and looke vppon Arden.

SP.SPEAKER: Ales.
SP.L: Sée Susan where thy quandam Maister lyes,
Sweete Arden smeard in bloode and filthy gore.

SP.SPEAKER: Susan.
SP.P: My brother, you, and I, shall rue this déede.

SP.SPEAKER: Ales
SP.L: Come susan help to lift his body forth,
And let our salt teares be his obsequies.

SP.SPEAKER: Mos.
SP.P: Now now Ales whether will you beare him

SP.SPEAKER: Ales.
SP.L: Sweete Mosbie art thou come?
Then weepe that will.
I haue my wishe in that I ioy thy sight.

SP.SPEAKER: Gre.
SP.P: Well it houes vs to be circumspect.
I for Francklin thinks that we haue murthred him.

SP.SPEAKER: Ales.
SP.L: I but he can not proue it for his lyfe,
Wele spend this night in daliance and in sport.

SP.SPEAKER: Mic.
SP.L: O mistres the Maior and all the watch,
Are comming towards our house with glaues & billes.

SP.SPEAKER: Ales.
SP.P: Make the dore fast, let them not come in,

SP.SPEAKER: Mos.
SP.P: Tell me swete Ales how shal I escape?

SP.SPEAKER: Ales.
SP.L: Out at the back dore, ouer the pyle of woode.
And for one night ly at the floure deluce,

SP.SPEAKER: Mos.
SP.P: That is the next way to betray my selfe.

SP.SPEAKER: Gre.
SP.L: Alas M. Arden the watch will take me here,
And cause suspition, where els would be none.

SP.SPEAKER: Ales
SP.L: Why take that way that M. Mosbie doeth,
But first conuey the body to the fields.

DIV1.STAGE: Then they beare the body into the fields

SP.SPEAKER: Mos.
SP.L: Until to morrow, swéete Ales now farewel,
And see you confesse nothing in any case.

SP.SPEAKER: Gre.
SP.L: Be resolute M. Ales, betray vs not,
But cleaue to vs as we wil stick to you,

SP.SPEAKER: Ales
SP.L: Now let the indge and iuries do their worst,
My house is cleare, and now I seare them not.

SP.SPEAKER: Susan
SP.L: As we went it snowed al the way,
Which makes me feare, our footesteps will be spyed.

SP.SPEAKER: Ales
SP.P: Peace foole, the snow wil couer them againe.

SP.SPEAKER: Susan
SP.P: But it had done before we came back againe.

SP.SPEAKER: Ales
SP.L: Hearke hearke, they knocke,
go Michaell let them in. Here enters the Maior and the Watch.
Now now M. Maior, haue you brought my husband home

SP.SPEAKER: Maior,
SP.P: I sawe him come into your house an hour agoe

SP.SPEAKER: Ales.
SP.P: You are deceiued, it was a Londoner,

SP.SPEAKER: Maior
SP.P: Mistres Arden know you not one that is called blacke Will.

SP.SPEAKER: Ales
SP.P: I know none such, what meane these questions
I haue the counsels warrand to aprehend him

SP.SPEAKER: Ales.
SP.L: I am glad it is no worse.
Why M. maior thinke you I harbour any such?

SP.SPEAKER: Ma.
SP.L: We are informd that here he is.
And therefore pardon vs, for we must search.

SP.SPEAKER: Ales
SP.L: I search and spare you not, through euery roome,
Were my husband at home, you would not offer this, Here enters Francklin.
M. Francklin what meane you come so sad.

SP.SPEAKER: Fra.
SP.P: Arden thy husband, and my fréend, is slaine,

SP.SPEAKER: Ales.
SP.P: Ah, by whome? M. Francklin can you tell?

SP.SPEAKER: Fra.
SP.L: I know not, but behind the abby,
There helyes murthred in most pittious case,

SP.SPEAKER: Mai.
SP.P: But M. Francklin are you sure tis he,

SP.SPEAKER: Fra.
SP.P: I am too sure, would God I were deceiued.

SP.SPEAKER: Ales.
SP.P: Finde out the Murthrers let them be knowne,

SP.SPEAKER: Fran.
SP.P: I so they shall, come you along with vs.

SP.SPEAKER: Ales.
SP.P: Wherefore?

SP.SPEAKER: Fran.
SP.P: know you this handtowel and this knyfe?

SP.SPEAKER: Su.
SP.L: Ah michael through this thy negligence.
Thou hast betraied and vndone vs all.

SP.SPEAKER: Mic.
SP.L: I was so affraide, I knew not what I did,
I thought I had throwne them both into the well.

SP.SPEAKER: Ales.
SP.L: It is the pigs bloode we had to supper.
But wherefore stay you? finde out the murthrers.

SP.SPEAKER: Ma.
SP.P: I feare me youle proue one of them your selfe.

SP.SPEAKER: Ale.
SP.P: I one of them, what meane such questions.

SP.SPEAKER: Fra.
SP.L: I feare me he was murthred in this house.
And carried to the fields, for from that place,
Backwards and forwards may you see,
The print of many feete within the snow,
And looke about this chamber where we are,
And you shall finde part of his giltles bloode,
For in his slipshoe did I finde some rushes.
Which argueth he was murthred in this roome.

SP.SPEAKER: Ma.
SP.L: Looke in the place where he was wont to sit.
Sèe see his blood it is too manifest,

SP.SPEAKER: Ales
SP.P: It is a cup of Wine that michaell shed.

SP.SPEAKER: Mic.
SP.P: I truely.

SP.SPEAKER: Fran.
SP.L: It is his bloode, which strumpet thou hast shed,
But if I liue thou and thy complices,
Which have conspired and wrought his death,
Shall rue it.

SP.SPEAKER: Ales
SP.L: Ah M. Francklin God and heauen can tell,
I loued him more then all the world beside.
But bring me to him let me sée his body.

SP.SPEAKER: Fra.
SP.L: Bring that villaine and mosbies sister too,
And one of you go to the flowre deluce.
And séeke for mosbie, and apprehend him to. Exeunt

SP.SPEAKER: Sh.
SP.L: The widdow chambly in her husbands dayes I kept
And now he's dead, she is growne so stout
She will not know her ould companions,
I came thither thinking to haue had
Harbour as I was wount
And she was ready to thrust me out at doores,
But whether she would or no, I got me up,
And as she followed me I spurnd her down the staires,
And broke her neck, and cut her tapsters throat,
And now I am going to sting them in the Temes,
I have the gould, what care I though it be knowne?
Ile crosse the water and take sanctuary.

DIV1.STAGE: Exit shakbag. Here enters the Maior, Mosbie. Ales, Francklin, Michaell and Susan.

SP.SPEAKER: Maior
SP.L: Sée M. Arden where your husband lyes.
Confesse this foule fault and be penitent.

SP.SPEAKER: Ales
SP.L: Arden sweete husband, what shall I say?
The more I found his name, the more he bleedes.
This bloode condemnes me, and in gushing foorth
Speakes as it falles, and askes me why I did it,
Forgiue me Arden, I repent me nowe,
And would my death saue thine, thou shouldst not dye,
Ryse vp swete Arden and enioy thy loue.
And frowne not on me when we mete in heauen,
In heauen I loue thee, though on earth I did not,

SP.SPEAKER: Maior
SP.P: Say Mosby what made thée murther him,

SP.SPEAKER: Fra.
SP.L: Study not for an asnwer, looke not down
His pursse and girdle found at thy beds head,
Witnes sufficiently thou didst the deede.
It bootles is to sweare thou didst it not,

SP.SPEAKER: Mos.
SP.L: I hyred black Will and Shakebagge, Ruffynes both,
And they and I haue done this murthrous deed,
But wherefore stay we?
Come and beare me hence.

SP.SPEAKER: Fran.
SP.L: Those Ruffins shall not escape,
I will vp to London, and get the counsels warrand to apprehend them. Exeunt.

SP.SPEAKER: Will.
SP.L: Shakebag I heare hath taken sanctuary,
But I am so pursued with hues and cryes,
For petty robberies that I haue done,
That I can come vnto no Sanctuary.
Therefore must I in some Oyster bote,
At last, be faine to go a boord some Hoye.
And so to Flushing there is no staying here,
At Sittinburgh the watch was like to take me.
And had I not with my buckler couerd my head,
And run full blanck, at all aduentures,
I am sure I had nere gone further then that place,
For the Constable had 20 warrands to apprehend me,
Besides that, I robbed him and his Man once at Gades hill,
Farewell England, Ile to Flushing now. Exit Will.

DIV1.STAGE: Here enters the Maior, Mosbye, Ales, Michaell, Susan, and Bradshaw.

SP.SPEAKER: Maior.
SP.P: Come make haste & bring away the prisoners.

SP.L: M. Arden you are now going to God,
And I am by the law condemned to die.
About a letter I brought from M. Grèene,
I pray you M. Arden speak the trueth,
Was I euer priuie to your intent or no?

SP.SPEAKER: Ales
SP.L: What should I say?
You brought me such a letter.
But I dare sweare thou knewest not the contents.
Leaue now to trouble me with wordly things.
And let me meditate vpon my sauiour Christ,
Whose bloode must saue me for the bloode I shed,

SP.SPEAKER: Mos.
SP.L: How long shall I live in this hell of griefe?
Conuey me from the presence of that strumpet.

SP.SPEAKER: Ales.
SP.L: Ah but for thee I had neuer beene strumpet
What can not oathes and prote stations doe?
When men haue opportunity to woe.
I was too young to sound thy villanies.
But now I finde it, and repent too late.

SP.SPEAKER: Su.
SP.L: Ah gentle brother, wherefore should I die.
I knew not of it, till the deed was don.

SP.SPEAKER: Mos.
SP.L: For thée I mourne more then for my selfe,
But let it suffice, I can not saue thee now,

SP.SPEAKER: Mic.
SP.L: And if your brother and my Mistres.
Had not promised me you in marriage,
I had nere giuen consent, to this foule deede.

SP.SPEAKER: Maior
SP.L: Leaue to accuse each other now,
And listen to the sentence I shall giue.
Beare Mosbie and his sister to London straight,
Where they in smithfield must be executed.
Beare M. Arden unto Canterburye,
Where her sentence is she must be burnt.
Michaell and Bradshaw in Feuershame
must suffer death.

SP.SPEAKER: Ales
SP.P: Let my death make a mends for all my sinnes,

SP.SPEAKER: Mos.
SP.L: Fy vpon women, this shall be my song,
But beare me hence, for I haue liued to long.

SP.P: Seing no hope on earth, in heauen is my hope.

SP.SPEAKER: Mic.
SP.P: Faith I care not seeing I die with Susan.

SP.SPEAKER: Brad.
SP.P: My bloode be on his head that gaue the sentence,

SP.SPEAKER: Maior
SP.P: To speedy execution with them all. Exeunt

SP.SPEAKER: Fran.
SP.L: Thus haue you seene the trueth of Ardens death
As for the Ruffins, Shakbag and blacke Will,
The one tooke Sanctuary, and being sent for out.
Was murthred in Southwark, as he past
To Greenewitch, where the Lord Protector lay.
Black Will was burnt in flushing on a stage.
Grèene was hanged at Osbridge in Rent.
The Painter fled, & how he dyed we know not.
But this aboue the rest is to be noted,
Arden lay murthred in that plot of ground,
Which he by force and violence held from Rede.
And in the grasse his bodyes print was seene,
Two yéeres and more after the deede was doone
Gentlemen we hope youle pardon this naked Tragedy,
Wherin no filed points are foilted in,
To make it gratious to the eare or eye.
For simple trusth is gratious enough:
And needes no other points of glosing stuffe.
